sen.j: 直務（じきむ）とは、荘園領主（本所・領家）が荘務権を直接執行して荘園の直接支配（所務）を行うこと。
sen.e: Jikimu refers to immediate dominance of shoen (manor in medieval Japan) by the lord of the manor (honjo (proprietor or guarantor of manor) and ryoke), executing Shomuken (the authority of the jurisdiction and the administration of Shoen).

sen.j: 鎌倉時代以後、荘園領主は荘官あるいは地頭、土倉などに現地における管理一切を任せて、定額の年貢納入を請負わせる制度が行われた。
sen.e: After the Kamakura period, the lord of the manor entrusted shokan (an officer governing shoen), jito (manager and lord of manor), doso (pawnbrokers and moneylenders) et al., with the total management of shoen to collect fixed land tax.

sen.j: 荘園の管理を請負った者を請負代官と呼んだ。
sen.e: Those who contracted to manage the shoen were called ukeoi daikan.

sen.j: 請負代官に就いたのが荘官であれば代官請、地頭であれば地頭請、守護であれば守護請と称した。
sen.e: When shokan took the post of ukeoi daikan, he was called daikanuke; when jito and shugo (provincial constable) took the post, they were called jitouke and shugouke respectively.

sen.j: だが、次第に年貢の未進・下地中分や半済の進行によって荘園からの収入が途絶える事態が生じるようになった。
sen.e: However, the revenues from shoen had gradually decreased because of the nonpayment of tribute, shitaji chubun (physical division of the land), and the introduction of hanzei (the system in the Muromachi Period where the Muromachi bakufu allowed military governors, or Shugo, to collect half of the taxes from manors and demesnes as military fund).

sen.j: 一方、現地では請負代官が農民から過酷な取立てを行って自己の収益にする事態も生じていた。
sen.e: Meanwhile, the ukeoi daikan levied harshly from farmers and made it their own profit on site.

sen.j: 領主の直務で著名な例は文亀元年（1501年）に前関白九条政基が守護細川氏の押領に対抗するために自己の荘園である和泉国日根荘に下向した例が知られる。
sen.e: There was a well-known example of feudal lord's jikimu; in 1501, former chief-adviser-to-the-Emperor Masamoto Kujo went to his shoen, Hinenosho, Izumi Province, in order to confront the seizure by Shugo (provincial constable) HOSOKAWA clan.

sen.j: 直務代官の著名な例としては寛正2年（1461年）に美作国新見荘の請負代官であった細川氏家臣安富智安を現地農民が排除して、領主である東寺に直務代官の派遣を要請して実現させた例が知られている。
sen.e: As for a well-known example of jikimu daikan, in 1461, farmers of Niimi-no-sho (shoen in Tetsuta district, Mimasaka Province) dismissed Ukeoi-daikan Chian YASUTOMI, a vassal of HOSOKAWA clan, and asked To-ji Temple, which was the feudal lord, to send jikimu daikan; the request was realized.
